awd_titl_txt: RUI: Collaboration to Enhance Participation of Minority and Undergraduate Students in Nuclear Science
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports a collaborative nuclear physics research program that will further our knowledge of nuclides with high ratios of neutrons to protons, which are interesting because they exhibit behavior not observed in stable nuclides.  Experiments will be carried out at the National Superconducting Cyclotron Laboratory (NSCL) and be "day-one" ready for the upcoming Facility for Rare Isotope Beams when construction is complete.   The experiments include: investigating heavy nuclei in excited states shortly before they fragment, exploring and characterizing particular states of beryllium nuclei, measuring separation energies of excited states of magnesium, as well as research and development of a new particle detector.  Undergraduate and graduate students will collaborate with faculty at several US institutions to further this work and learn valuable highly technical skills. The projects will be evaluated through peer review and disseminated through presentations at national conferences, Ph.D. theses, and journal articles.

The PIs of this award are members of the MoNA-LISA collaboration, and the experiments they have planned will exploit the capabilities of the equipment that was developed at NSCL by the collaboration (a modular neutron array and a large area scintillation array).  Neutron-rich nuclides are very short-lived and decay by prompt neutron emission, making the MoNA-LISA system the ideal tool to investigate these nuclei.  Projects include analyzing data, implementing novel techniques to identify better and resolve isomeric nuclear states, measuring neutron-unbound states in neutron-rich nuclei, characterizing pre-fragmentation dynamics after relativistic beams interact with targets, as well as research and development toward a new gas electron multiplier based segmented target.  Future experiments focus on higher Z nuclides that are possible with the current experimental setup.  The students will learn valuable skills utilized in all facets of research including detector construction, data collection and analysis, and dissemination.

por.por_cntn:
The undergraduate nuclear physics research group at Augustana College was supported by this grant to study neutron-rich nuclides, and to maintain and improve experimental equipment. Experiments utilized the National Superconducting Cyclotron Laboratory located on the campus of Michigan State University (MSU). Undergraduate Augustana students and the primary investigator worked on experiment design, participation and analysis, and dissemination of experimental results with investigators from the MoNA (Modular Neutron Array) collaboration. Through this work, undergraduate students gained valuable research experience that helped them pursue their career goals or achieve acceptance into graduate school. This particular grant supported collaborative work between three undergraduate institutions, Augustana College, Gettysburg College, and Wabash College, and one historically black college institution, Hampton University. This led to an increased participation in nuclear physics among underrepresented groups and fostered greater connection between multiple institutions.

The Intellectual Merit of the supported work included studies of neutron-rich nuclides to improve our theoretical understanding of these systems, and to maintain and develop experimental devices. Members of the Augustana research team participated in experiments and analyses on nuclides 25O, 25,26F, 31Ne, 32Mg, and 33,34Al, produced in four different experiments. The primary investigator and undergraduate students were co-authors on three published papers including a publication about the Si-Be segmented target, and a publication on comparison of neutron scattering data to simulation. Multiple talks by undergraduate students and the PI disseminated additional results and progress at the April or Division of Nuclear Physics Meetings of the American Physics Society. In addition, a new charged particle detector telescope concept was developed and funded by a separate grant during the same time. The first analysis of data from it was partially supported by this grant.

The Broader Impacts of the work was in providing opportunities to do research at a R1 level facility for Augustana undergraduates and collaborating on analyses with graduate student researchers at MSU along with undergraduates from the MoNA collaboration. Six undergraduates participated in this work. Three of the students have graduated and are performing nuclear physics research for their PhD at the University of Notre Dame, Michigan State University, and Western Michigan University. The three other students are planning to apply to STEM graduate school programs.
